Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Cybermanufacturing: Smartphone Actuated Optical Lab-on-a-Chip Systems for Biomanufacturing and Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EAGER project develops computational tools to enable lab-on-a-chip devices that can be optically actuated using smartphones and tablets. Low-cost, portable lab-on-a-chip systems can impact a wide variety of applications including biomolecule production, point-of-care medical diagnostics, newborn screening, and biochemical sensing.

The developed algorithms and software will coordinate the motions of droplets of chemicals on light-actuated digital microfluidic (LADM) chips by using moving patterns of projected light to optically actuate the droplets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project's goal is to develop algorithms to enable automated manipulation of multiple droplets in parallel on light-actuated digital microfluidic (LADM) chips optically actuated by smartphones and tablets (Figure 1). The project scope broadened to include coordination and coverage with multiple robots.


Intellectual Merit:

The research has developed algorithms for assignment and coordination of multiple droplets, and has been extended to algorithms for coordination and coverage with multiple robots.

1. Algorithms for optimal assignment of sets of droplets translating from an initial formation to a variable goal formation. The novel aspect is the ability to perform optimal assignments of droplets translating in the plane to a variable goal formation, whose size or location can be varied, from a known initial formation. This enables automated motion planning of multiple droplets in parallel on light-actuated digital microfluidic (LADM) chips.

2. Algorithms for the assignment and trajectory planning of multiple robots with variable goal formations in 2D and 3D. The developed new algorithms compute the optimal assignments and collision-free trajectories of multiple robots to move from an initial formation to a variable goal formation (where the shape of the goal formation is given, and both its scale and location parameters can be optimized). This is useful for efficient motion coordination of hundreds of robots (Figure 2). Example applications include the collision-free coordination of droplets in light-actuated digital microfluidic systems, and coordination of multiple mobile robots (for example, coordination of a large number of drones for aerial entertainment).

3. Algorithms for line coverage, the inspection of linear environment features using multiple robots. Linear features include power lines and road networks, which can be modeled as line segments; all points along the segments must be inspected. When the features are distributed over large areas, this necessitates the use of multiple robots (e.g., drones) simultaneously to complete the coverage tasks in a timely manner while respecting robot resource constraints (e.g,, battery life). This is especially important for rapid assessment and response after natural disasters such as storms and earthquakes.

The research has led to publications at the IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation, and the International Workshop on the Foundations of Robotics.


Broader Impact:

The developed assignment and trajectory planning algorithms enable time and energy efficient motions of multiple agents as they move from one formation to another formation. This capability is useful for both droplets in digital microfluidic lab-on-chip devices, and ground and aerial robots. The algorithms and software for multi-robot coverage can impact disciplines such as earth and ocean sciences by providing the capability to rapidly perform remote sensing using multiple drones. They are also useful for rapid inspection of physical infrastructure such as roads during disaster assessment and response. A website for line and area coverage of user-specified regions by multiple drones has been developed. The software generates drone flight plans that can be directly downloaded to the drones.

The project has supported a PhD student, and involved Masters, undergraduate, and high school students in research. The research results have been incorporated into Robotics courses at UNC Charlotte, and the algorithms have been demonstrated during outreach activities for K-12 students in the Robotics lab at UNC Charlotte.
